questions.text: Which of the alphabets mark the C cells in the section of the thyroid gland shown below?
questions.solution:
Alphabet B marks the C cells in the section of the thyroid gland.

The C-cells (or parafollicular cells) are present between the follicular cells and the basement membrane or between the follicles. They secrete calcitonin.

The thyroid gland is covered by a fibrous capsule with septae dividing it into lobules. These lobules contain follicles lined by follicular cells. The shape of the follicular cells depends on the activity of the gland. They're squamous in the inactive state, cuboidal to columnar in the active state. The cavity of the follicle contains colloid which appears pink in H and E staining.

questions.text: All of the following are components responsible for the countercurrent mechanism in the kidney except _____.

choices.text: Sodium outflow in thick ascending limb
Water outflow in thin descending limb
Sodium outflow in thin ascending limb
Flow of tubular fluid from PCT to DCT

questions.solution:
Thin ascending limb is not a component of the countercurrent mechanism. 

The loop of Henle function as countercurrent multipliers and vasa recta as countercurrent exchangers.

The functioning of the loop of Henle depends upon:

  1. High permeability of the thin descending limb to water ( via aquaporin-1)
  2. Active transport of Na+ and Cl- from the thick ascending limb
  3. Inflow of tubular fluid from proximal tubule and outflow to the distal tubule.

Note: The thin ascending limbs of juxtamedullary nephrons are permeable to Na+ and Cl- and hence do contribute passively to countercurrent multiplication. However, among the options provided, Option C is the best answer as the other options are directly responsible for the countercurrent mechanism.

questions.text: A 15-year-old patient presents with symptoms of night blindness, loss of peripheral vision and says that far off objects have begun to look blurry, despite wearing lenses. Fundoscopic examination is shown in the image below. This autosomal recessive condition is caused by the deficiency of which of the following enzymes?
questions.solution:
The fundoscopic image shows Gyrate atrophy of retina and choroid which is associated with an Ornithine-Δ-aminotransferase deficiency.

 

Gyrate atrophy of the retina and choroid is an autosomal recessive disorder, caused by a deficiency of the enzyme Ornithine-Δ-aminotransferase, a vitamin B6-dependent mitochondrial matrix enzyme which catalyzes the conversion of L-ornithine, a non-proteinaceous amino acid, to proline and glutamic acid. It plays a critical role in cellular detoxiﬁcation by disposing of ornithine derived from dietary arginine which results in an increase in plasma ornithine concentrations.

Patients classically present in the first decade of life with nyctalopia, early cataract formation and myopia, with fundus exam revealing circular patches of chorioretinal atrophy around the peripheral fundus. 

Other options:

Option A: Ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency leads to lethargy progressing to coma, protein aversion, intellectual disability, hyperammonemia

Option C: Argininosuccinate lyase leads to Arginosuccinic acidemia with symptoms similar to ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency

Option D: Branched chain ketoacid dehydrogenase deficiency leads to Maple syrup urine disease with symptoms of lethargy, vomiting, encephalopathy, seizures, intellectual disability, “maple syrup” odor, protein intolerance

questions.text: A 64-year-old male patient is brought to the clinic for evaluation of frequent falls. He also complains of difficulty swallowing, urinary incontinence, and impotence. On examination, gross orthostatic changes in the blood pressure are noted. He has ocular dysmetria, scanning dysarthric speech, and gait ataxia. MRI of the brain shows atrophy of multiple regions of the brain and characteristic findings shown below. Which of the following will be the predominant pathological feature in this patient?

choices.text: Neuronal loss and accumulation of tau-containing neurofibrillary tangles in the frontotemporal regions
Ballooned neurons and astrocytic plaques around the astrocytes in the anterior parietal lobes
Pallor of the substantia nigra and locus ceruleus with Lewy bodies
Atrophy of the cerebellum with alpha-synuclein containing inclusions in the oligodendrocytes

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette describes a case of multiple system atrophy with predominant cerebellar atrophy (MSA-C subtype). The arrow points to the 'hot cross bun' sign seen in MSA-C. This condition is characterized by atrophy of the cerebellum with alpha-synuclein-containing inclusions in the oligodendrocytes.

Multiple system atrophy:

It is a sporadic disease that affects several functional systems in the brain which is characterized by primary pathology in the glial cells.

The predominant clinical features of MSA-C are cerebellar dysfunction that manifests as gait ataxia, limb ataxia, ataxic dysarthria, and cerebellar disturbances of eye movements which manifests as ocular dysmetria, gaze-evoked nystagmus, or impaired smooth pursuits with the saccadic intrusion. Dysphagia is a prominent symptom and the speech pattern is scanning dysarthria. Autonomic dysfunction includes orthostatic hypotension, erectile dysfunction, urinary incontinence, nocturnal enuresis, urinary retention, and hesitancy. Sleep and breathing pattern abnormalities may also be seen. Patients with MSA-P have predominant Parkinsonian features in association with the other features described above. MRI shows a characteristic 'hot cross bun sign'. There will be atrophy of the putamen, pons, and middle cerebellar peduncles.

The pathological features in MSA mimic the clinical presentation of the condition. In this patient with cerebellar dysfunction, there will be atrophy of the cerebellum, including the peduncles, pons, basal pontis, inferior olive of the medulla. The diagnostic glial inclusions are demonstrated in the oligodendrocytes with silver impregnation. They contain alpha-synuclein as well as ubiquitin. Autonomic symptoms are related to cell loss from the catecholaminergic nuclei of the medulla.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with COVID-19 has been started on a "cocktail therapy" of Casirivimab and Imdevimab. What is the mechanism of action of these drugs?
questions.solution:
Casirivimab and Imdevimab are entry inhibitors.

Casirivimab and imdevimab are monoclonal antibodies that are specifically directed against the spike protein of SARS-CoV-2, designed to block the virus’ attachment and entry into human cells.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presented with fever, chills, and tender inguinal lymphadenopathy. Smears prepared from the discharge of these swellings revealed bacteria with bipolar staining. Which stain was used to prepare these smears?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of fever, chills, tender inguinal lymphadenopathy, and a smear showing bipolar staining of bacteria is highly suggestive of bubonic plague caused by Yersinia pestis. The stain used for this organism is the Wayson stain containing methylene blue.

Plague is a zoonotic disease caused by Yersinia pestis. It is a gram-negative, non-motile, coccobacillus. The reservoirs of infection are wild rodents like field mice, gerbils, skunks, etc. In India, the gerbil (Tatera indica) is the main reservoir. The important vector of plague is rat flea (Xenopsylla cheopis).

Humans acquire the disease by the bite of an infected flea, by direct contact with the tissues of the infected animal, or by droplet infection from cases of pneumonic plague. 

Human plague mainly presents as:

Bubonic plague- This is the most common type of disease. The patient develops a sudden fever, chills, headache, and painful lymphadenitis. Within a few days, the lymph nodes in the groin, axilla, or neck enlarge and are called buboes. This is followed by the suppuration of the buboes. Bubonic plague cannot spread from person to person as the bacilli are locked up in the buboes and do not find a way or easy exit.

Pneumonic plague- It develops as a complication of bubonic-septicemic plague. 

Septicemic plague- It occurs when the infection spreads to the blood.

Laboratory diagnosis- Microscopy reveals bacteria that show characteristic bipolar staining or safety pin appearance when stained with Wayson's stain. Antibodies to the F1 antigen of the bacteria can also be demonstrated by passive hemagglutination. PCR is used for a rapid presumptive diagnosis.

Treatment- Streptomycin, doxycycline, and chloramphenicol can be used.

Other options:

Options B & D- Albert's and Neisser's stains are used to stain Corynebacterium diphtheriae. They show the bacteria with metachromatic granules arranged in chinese-letter or cuneiform pattern.

Option C- Warthin-starry stain is used to stain Bartonella henselae which causes cat-scratch disease.

questions.text: Which of the following IPC sections is not related to grievous injury?
questions.solution:
IPC Section 319 defines hurt (not grievous hurt) that includes bodily pain, infirmity, or disease caused to any individual.

Grievous hurt or injury is defined to include injuries such as emasculation, permanent damage to eyesight(either eye), permanent damage to hearing(either ear), damage to any member or joint, destruction or permanent impairment of the power of any member or joint, permanent disfigurement of the head or face, fracture or dislocation of bone or tooth, and any hurt that endangers the victim's life or causes them severe bodily pain thereby impairing their ability to follow their daily routine for a period of 20 days. 

Other options:

  • Section 320 - defines grievous hurt
  • Section 326 - Punishment for voluntarily causing grievous hurt by dangerous weapon(imprisonment up to 10 years with fine)
  • Section 331: Causing grievous hurt to extort confession. (imprisonment up to 10 years with fine). (imprisonment up to 10 years with fine).

Other IPC sections related to grievous hurt:

  • Sec 322: Voluntary causation of grievous hurt.
  • Sec 325: Punishment for voluntarily causing grievous hurt (imprisonment up to 7 years with fine)
  • Sec 329: Causing grievous hurt to extort property (imprisonment up to 10 years with fine)
  • Sec 333: Causing hurt to deter public servant from the duty (imprisonment up to 10 years with fine)
  • Sec 335: Causing grievous hurt on grave or sudden provocations (imprisonment with 4years + or –fine)
  • Sec 338: Causing grievous hurt by act endangering life/safety of others (imprisonment with 2years + or –fine)

questions.text: Which of the following surgery is done commonly in Tubotympanic type of CSOM?
questions.solution:
Tympanoplasty is done commonly in Tubotympanic type of CSOM.

It is the eradication of disease from the middle ear and reconstruction of hearing (ossiculoplasty) with or without grafting of the tympanic membrane.

Myringoplasty is the term given for closure of perforation of tympanic membrane done to check repeated infections from external ear.

questions.text: A 51-year-old diabetic male presented with headache and eye pain for a few months. He also reports difficulty in driving at night and frequent changes in presbyopic glasses. On examination, his Intraocular pressure (IOP) was 22 mm Hg and a laminar dot sign was seen on fundoscopy. Which of the following is incorrect regarding the other fundus changes seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the finding of the laminar dot sign and raised IOP is suggestive of primary open-angle glaucoma and a cup: disc ratio of less than 0.5 is not seen in this condition.

Primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) is chronic, progressive optic neuropathy. It is mostly seen in more than 40 years of age and it runs in family. The major risk factors are diabetes mellitus and myopia.

Most often patients having POAG presents with headaches, frequent changes in presbyopic correction, and difficulty in dark adaptation. 

The fundus examination in glaucoma shows a cup: disc ratio of more than 0.5 and an asymmetry between the cup: disc ratio of two eyes of more than 0.2. 

Other changes include:

  • Narrowing and notching of the neuroretinal rim (NRR)
  • Disc hemorrhages extending from the NRR onto the retina
  • Bayoneting sign due to the double angulation of a blood vessel.
  • Loss of nasal NRR is characterized by developing space between the NRR and the central retinal vasculature
  • The laminar dor sign is the grey dot-like fenestration in the exposed lamina cribrosa as the NRR recedes.

Patients with affected first-degree relatives, diabetics, and myopes should be examined regularly after the age of 40 years to rule out glaucoma.

Medical, laser, or surgical therapies can be used to achieve a target pressure of 16- 18 mm Hg that results in stabilization of POAG in most patients. Laser therapy for POAG consists of laser trabeculoplasty and is indicated only if the patient is refractory to medications and not compliant for surgery.

questions.text: During the COVID 19 pandemic, plastic coverall used by a healthcare worker is disposed  in ________.
questions.solution:
The plastic coverall used by a healthcare worker during COVID 19 pandemic is disposed in the red bin.

In addition to the current BMW Management rules, the following measures are proposed

  • Dedicated sanitation workers deputed only to collect COVID 19 BMW
  • It is mandatory for all BMW bags and containers from COVID 19 areas to carry "COVID 19 WASTE" label
  • Keep seperate colour coded bins with foot operated lids
  • The inner and outer surfaces of these containers must be disinfected daily with 1% sodium hypochlorite solution
  • To ensure no leaks, double layers (2 bags) are used
  • Records of COVID 19 waste are seperately maintained

questions.text: A cross-sectional study was conducted among a group of 600 individuals. 200 individuals were diseased, and out of this, 160 were identified correctly by a screening test. Among the 400 normal individuals, 320 were identified correctly as negative for the disease. Calculate the positive likelihood ratio of the above test.
questions.solution:
The positive likelihood ratio of the above screening test is 4.

The positive likelihood ratio deals with the likelihood of a patient having the disease obtaining a positive test result. This is used to assess how good a diagnostic test is and helps in selecting an appropriate diagnostic test for a specific disease.

It is the ratio of the true positive rate to the false-positive rate

Positive likelihood ratio = sensitivity / (1-specificity)

In the above scenario:

  Diseased individuals Normal individuals
Test positive 160 (TP) 80  (FP)
Test negative 40   (FN) 320 (TN)

TP: True positive

FP: False positive

TN: True negative

FN: False negative

Using the above values, we get the sensitivity and specificity.

  • Sensitivity= TP/TP+FN = 160/200
  • Specificity= TN/FP+TN = 320/400

Therefore, positive likelihood ratio= sensitivity/ 1- specificity

= [160/200]/ [1-(320/400)] = 4

Note:

The negative likelihood ratio deals with the likelihood of a patient having the disease and obtaining a negative test result.

Negative likelihood ratio = (1- sensitivity) /specificity.

questions.text: Which among the following is COVID appropriate behaviour?

choices.text: Maintain a distance of at least 2 feet in all public places
Remove the upper string of the mask first followed by the lower string
Tie the lower string of the mask first followed by upper string
The external pleats of the mask should face downwards

questions.solution:
The external pleats of the mask should face downwards is the only COVID appropriate behaviour in the above options.

 COVID appropriate behaviours prevent the transmission of COVID 19 infection. Important ones are:

  • Greet without physical contact
  • Maintain a distance of at least 6 feet in all public places.
  • Wear reusable hand-made face-cover or mask, at all times. While wearing a mask the nasal clip should be present over the nose and external pleats should face downwards. Open the mask pleats so that the mask covers the mouth and nose. Tie the upper strings of the mask first followed by lower strings. Do not touch the front of the mask. Replace the mask every 8 hours or when damp. While removing, the mask, remove the lower string of the mask first followed by the upper string. Dispose the mask and wash your hands.
  • Avoid touching eyes, nose, and mouth
  • Maintain respiratory hygiene. Cover your nose and mouth when you cough or sneeze with a tissue or handkerchief. If there is no tissue or handkerchief, always cover your nose and mouth with a bent elbow before coughing or sneezing. Immediately wash your hands after that.
  • Wash hands frequently and thoroughly or sanitise with alcohol-based sanitiser.
  • Regularly clean and disinfect frequently touched surfaces by wearing gloves.
  • Do not spit in the open
  • Avoid unnecessary travel and discourage crowd and social gatherings.

questions.text: Identify the ECG.
questions.solution:
The above ECG is suggestive of dextrocardia based on the following features.

  • Lead I is inverted with a negative P wave, QRS complex & T wave.
  • P wave is inverted in aVR and aVL
  • Reversal of the usual pattern of Lead aVR.
  • There is a loss of normal R-wave progression from V1 - V6 with dominant S waves throughout.
  • Right-axis deviation

Differential diagnosis:

Accidental reversal of right and left arm electrodes may produce similar findings as dextrocardia in the limb leads, but with normal appearances in the precordial leads.

 

Reference - The ECG, by John Hampton, Page no. 57.

questions.text: Choose the false statement regarding Convalescent plasma therapy in COVID 19.

choices.text: Use should be avoided in patients with IgA deficiency or immunoglobulin allergy
Plasma IgG titer (against S-protein RBD) above 1:640 should be used
Recipients should be closely monitored for several hours post-transfusion
Convalescent plasma therapy is useful only in severe COVID 19 cases

questions.solution:
The latest MoHFW COVID-19 treatment guidelines do not recommend convalescent plasma in severe disease.

Convalescent plasma may be considered in patients with moderate disease who are not improving (oxygen requirement is progressively increasing) despite the use of steroids. 

Special prerequisites while considering convalescent plasma include: 

  • ABO compatibility and cross-matching of the donor plasma is required 
  • Plasma IgG titer (against S-protein receptor binding domain) above 1:640 should be used
  • The recipient should be closely monitored for several hours post-transfusion for any transfusion related adverse events  
  • Use should be avoided in patients with IgA deficiency or immunoglobulin allergy

The recommended dose is 4-13ml/kg. Usually, a 200 ml single dose is given.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male was treated for atrial fibrillation with a drug showing the following adverse effect as shown. He now comes with palpitations and restlessness. What ECG pattern do you most likely expect to see in this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient being treated with amiodarone (blue man syndrome) for his atrial fibrillation will present with atrial flutter rather than atrial fibrillation. Atrial flutter will show characteristic flutter waves on ECG.

In some cases of atrial fibrillation treated with antiarrhythmic drugs which slow atrial conduction velocity and can promote reentry, particularly flecainide, propafenone, or amiodarone, may have a presentation of atrial flutter rather than fibrillation.

Flecainide, Propafenone (Group 1C) cause a slight increase in PR interval, increased QRS duration, and no change in QT interval.

Amiodarone (Group 3) but also has some group 1A properties. It causes increased PR interval, QRS duration, and QT interval.

Other options

Option A: Pseudo s waves are seen in AVNRT.

Option C: 3 different p wave morpholgoies are characteristic of multifocal atrial tachycardia.

Option D: Wide QRS complexes are generally seen in Ventricular tachycardias.

questions.text: According to the CEAP classification, what will be the C stage in this patient?
questions.solution:
The image above shows dilated, tortuous veins of the lower limb or varicose veins, and is classified as C2A according to the CEAP classification for chronic venous disorders. 

According to the CEAP (Clinical-Etiology-Anatomy-Pathophysiology) classification, the clinical classification of venous disease is as follows: For clinical classification:

  • C0: no signs of venous disease
  • C1: telangiectasia or reticular veins
  • C2: varicose veins
  • C3: edema
  • C4a: pigmentation or eczema (including malleolar flare)
  • C4b: lipodermatosclerosis or atrophie blanche.  Lipodermatosclerosis (LDS) refers to chronic inflammation and fibrosis of the skin and subcutaneous tissues. This is seen as a tight, contracted, 'woody leg' on examination. Atrophie blanche, which refers to localized areas of white, atrophic skin surrounded by telangiectasia and pigmentation.
  • C5: healed venous ulcer
  • C6: active venous ulcer

Each clinical class is further characterized depending upon whether the patient is symptomatic (S) or asymptomatic (A). Since the question stem does not mention any symptoms (S), the best answer would be C2A amongst the given choices.

Image A - tortuous dilated veins - C2

Image B - Atrophie blanche - C4b

Image C - fan-shaped telangiectasia - C4c

Image D -  venous ulcer with active crusts - healing venous ulcer - C5.

 

The images below show C5 and C6 - healed and active venous ulcers respectively.

Varicose veins refer to a condition in which there is tortuous dilatation of subcutaneous veins due to venous insufficiency. Patients complain of a sensation of heaviness, burning, and aching over the affected area or whole limb, that increases throughout the day or on prolonged standing. Compression and elevation relieve the symptoms.

Diagnosis is mainly using duplex ultrasound. MR venography or intravenous ultrasound(IVUS) may be used occasionally.

Treatment is achieved using modalities such as compression, laser ablation, endothermal ablation, radiofrequency ablation, endovenous glue, ultrasound-guided foam sclerotherapy, open surgery, etc.

questions.text: A young man presents to the emergency with a painful scrotum. On examination, the patient is febrile, scrotal erythema and on lifting the testis the pain is relieved. What is the most likely cause of the patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario with positive Prehn's sign is suggestive of acute Epididymo-orchitis. 

A positive Prehn’s sign is used to differentiate epididymis from testicular torsion. A Prehn’s sign is said to be positive when the pain gets relieved on lifting the testis. If it persists, it is likely to be testicular torsion.

Epididymo-orchitis is an inflammatory condition affecting the epididymitis and testis. The infection reaches the epididymitis from a primary infection of the urethra, seminal vesicles, or prostate. In young men, it is sexually acquired while in older men it is secondary to a urinary tract infection. It can occur post catheterization or instrumentation as well. 

Chlamydia trachomatis is the most common cause of acute epididymitis in young, sexually active males. In older men(>40yrs) with bladder outflow obstruction, epididymitis results from a urinary infection, most commonly due to Escherichia coli.

Clinical features include pain and redness in the scrotum, fever, and tenderness of the scrotum.

Initial investigations include urine specimen for culture, Nucleic acid amplification testing(NAAT), and a urethral swab to check for signs of infection. An ultrasound of the epididymis can show inflammation and abscess formation if any. 

Treatment is by antibiotics and scrotal support.

Note: 

A common differential is a testicular torsion which needs urgent surgical exploration. A Prehn's sign is used to differentiate torsion from epididymo-orchitis.

Chronic tuberculous epididymo-orchitis presents as a painless swelling of the scrotum with a firm enlarged epididymis, beading of the vas deferens, and a normal testis on palpation.Beading of the vas deferens is due to subepithelial tubercle formation and is specific to genital tuberculosis.

questions.text: A 42-year-old asymptomatic woman is diagnosed with COVID 19 infection. Her CT chest is unremarkable. She was incidentally diagnosed with gall stones 2 months back and wishes to get an elective surgery done. As per the American Society of Anesthesiologists, how long is the suggested wait time for elective surgeries after diagnosis of COVID 19?
questions.solution:
For asymptomatic and mildly symptomatic COVID 19 positive patients, elective surgeries can be planned 4 weeks from the date of diagnosis.

The American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) recommended waiting time for elective surgery from the date of diagnosis of COVID-19 infection are as follows:  

  • 4 weeks for an asymptomatic patient or recovery from only mild, non-respiratory symptoms
  • 6 weeks for symptomatic patients with cough/dyspnea not requiring hospitalization
  • 8 to 10 weeks for symptomatic patients who required hospitalization and/or diabetic patients and/or immunocompromised
  • 12 weeks for patients that had to be admitted to the ICU due to COVID 19  

The American College of Surgeons recommends non-operative management, if feasible and safe for the patient in surgical emergencies in a COVID-19 positive patient or is at high clinical suspicion of COVID-19.

If the surgery is required in such patients, then proper personal protective equipment should be utilized and precautions to be taken to protect the health care team.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a history of intermittent blood in stools and altered bowel habits for the past 3 months. After a detailed evaluation, she is diagnosed with rectal adenocarcinoma which is located at the anal sphincters and distal third of the rectum. There is no nodal or distant metastasis. What is the preferred management in this patient?

(APR-Abdominoperineal resection)
questions.solution:
Abdominoperineal resection with permanent colostomy is preferred for this patient. 

Abdominoperineal resection is the complete excision of the rectum and anus by dissecting through the abdomen and perineum followed by the creation of a permanent colostomy. This is indicated in patients where:

  • Tumor involving the anal sphincters
  • Tumor is too close to the sphincters to obtain a negative margin
  • Sphincter-saving surgery is not possible

This surgery increases the complete resection rates, reduces the risk of local perforation and local recurrence.

Other options:

Option A- Anterior resection is the resection of the proximal rectum or rectosigmoid above the peritoneal reflection through the abdominal approach. It is the term used for anterior proctosigmoidectomy with colorectal anastomosis. 

Option B- Hartman's operation is indicated in elderly and frail patients who has poor anal sphincter function or postoperative incontinence. In this surgery, colorectal excision is done along with the closure of the rectal stump and permanent proximal colostomy.

Option D- Endoluminal stent is indicated in patients with obstructive rectal carcinoma and also as a palliative procedure. Only rectosigmoid and upper rectal tumors are suitable for stenting because, in low cancers, stent impingement results in tenesmus.

questions.text: A 37-week primigravida has mild labor pains for 20 hours and the cervix is persistently 1 cm dilated but non-effaced. What would be the appropriate management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of either prolonged latent phase. The appropriate management is to sedate the patient and wait.

The first stage of labour consists of two phases :

  1. Latent phase: It is considered to begin at the time the woman first perceives regular uterine contractions and is characterized by gradual cervical change (up to 5 cm of cervical dilatation).
  2. Active phase: This follows the latent phase and is characterized by regular painful uterine contractions, cervical effacement, and rapid cervical dilatation from 5 cm to full dilatation.

A latent phase that exceeds 20 hours in primigravidae or 14 hours in multiparae is termed as a prolonged latent phase of labour. Bed rest is the preferred treatment unless there is any indication for expediting the delivery.

The presence of false labour pains for a long time may be confused with a prolonged latent phase. The differences between them include

Features True labour pains False labour pains
Cervical dilatation and effacement Present Absent
Pain Lower abdomen and back, radiating to thighs Lower abdomen only
Show Present Absent
Bag of water Formed Absent
Relief with enema No Yes

Augmentation with oxytocin is done only in those patients who even after therapeutic rest continue to be in a prolonged latent phase. There is no indication of the cesarean section unless cephalopelvic disproportion is present. Amniotomy is not useful and should be avoided in patients with prolonged latent phases due to the risk of infections.

Related Pearl: Abnormalities of first stage of labor

Labor pattern Criteria- Nullipara Criteria-Multipara Treatment
Prolonged latent phase >20 hrs >14hrs

Bed rest

Oxytocin or cesarean delivery 
Protraction of dilatation <1.2cm/hr 1.5cm/hr

Expectant management and support

Cesarean delivery for CPD
Protraction of descent <1cm/hr <2cm/hr
Secondary arrest of dilatation >2hr >2hr

Check for CPD:

If no CPD- administer oxytocin

If CPD present- cesarean delivery

 
Arrest of descent >1hr >1hr
 CPD- Cephalopelvic disproportion

Related Pearl: Partograph

Partograph types:

WHO Modified Partograph (2000)

  • No latent phase
  • Vaginal examination: This should be done no less than every 4 hours to assess cervical dilatation, descent of the fetal head, and moulding of skull bones. More frequent examination is only undertaken if indicated.
  • Charting starts at 4 cm of cervical dilation.
  • Colour of liquor mentioned as C-clear, B-blood stained, M-meconium stained.
  • Moulding mentioned:
    • bones are separated and sutures can be easily felt - (0)
    • bones touching (1+)
    • bones overlapping but can be reduced(2+)
    • bones severely overlapping and irreducible ( 3+).
  • Alert line reflects the average rate of cervical dilation of the slowest quintile of term primigravidas, if dilation slows or ceases, the partograph plot will cross the alert line.
  • Alert line: at 4 cm dilation and expected dilation of 1 cm/hour.
  • Action line is 2–4 hours after the alert line, which prompts interventions to accelerate labor or perform cesarean delivery.
  • Higher rates of perinatal mortality are associated with delays of 4 hours or more after the alert line.
  • Contractions measured for a span of 10 min (duration noted) and measured every 30 min (1 square = half hour).
  • Pulse: record every 30 minutes and mark with a dot (•).
  • Blood pressure: record every 4 hours and mark with arrows, unless the patient has a hypertensive disorder or pre-eclampsia, in which case record every 30 minutes.
  • Temperature: record every 4 hours.

WHO Composite Partograph: It is same as modified except for it has latent phase and charting done at 3 cm.

WHO Simplified Partograph: WHO further modified the partograph for use by skilled attendants in health centers. This simplified partograph is colour coded.

  • The area to the left of the alert line in the cervicograph is coloured green, representing normal progress.
  • The area to the right of the action line is coloured red, indicating dangerously slow progress in labour.
  • The area in between the alert and action line is coloured amber, indicating the need for greater vigilance.

questions.text: As a senior resident in the OBG department, You would consider uterine artery embolization as a treatment option in all of the following cases except ________

choices.text: Prior to the removal of Placenta accreta in Multiparous woman
Patient diagnosed with calcified and pedunculated submucous fibroids

questions.solution:
Uterine artery embolization is indicated in all the above-given cases except in a patient with calcified and pedunculated submucous fibroids.

A calcified fibroid does not shrink with the procedure. The pedunculated fibroids can fall off after the procedure resulting in intrauterine or peritoneal infections.

Hence, the calcified, submucous, and subserous types of fibroids are contraindications for this procedure. 

Other indications for Uterine artery embolization(UAE) include,

  • Postpartum hemorrhage.
  • Placenta accreta to reduce bleeding prior to placental removal, or caesarean delivery.
  • This technique is most suited for menorrhagia in a multiparous woman

Technique:

  • Under local sedation, bilateral UAE is ap­proached through percutaneous femoral catheterization.
  • It is done using polyvinyl alcohol (PVA), gel foam particles or metal coils.

Embolization reduces vascularity and the size of the fibroid in 3–4 months

Advantages of UAE:

  • No major surgery.
  • No intraoperative bleeding.
  • Short hospital stay.
  • Less abdominal adhesions.

Related Pearl: Contraindications to Uterine artery embolization

Absolute contraindications:

  • GnRH agonist use
  • Asymptomatic fibroids
  • Pregnancy
  • Pelvic inflammatory disease
  • Uterine malignancy
  • Calcified fibroid

Relative contraindications:

  • A desire for future pregnancy: Poor uterine perfusion and pelvic adhesions following UAE would negatively impact fertility, and result in obstetric complications or adverse fetal effects.
  • Postmenopausal status: The procedure is indicated primarily for premenopausal women since fibroids tend to decrease in size and symptoms improve or resolve after menopause. An enlarging uterus after menopause should raise the suspicion of malignancy and careful follow-up is warranted.
  • Subserosal or submucosal fibroids: They are pedunculated and may detach either intraperitoneally or within the uterine cavity. Detachment may be associated with sterile peritonitis or intrauterine infection.
  • Size or number of fibroids: The volume of necrosis after UAE in a large fibroid uterus can be substantial with a proportionate level of postprocedural pain and risk of infection.
  • Contraindications to radiologic contrast agents.

questions.text: A 30-year-old G2P1L1 woman is 18 weeks pregnant. She mentions that her previous labor was prolonged and tedious and eventually the doctor used an instrument to deliver her first child. Which of the following measurements would point towards the diagnosis of cephalo-pelvic disproportion at the pelvic inlet?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of the diagnosis as cephalo-pelvic disproportion (CPD). Cephalo-pelvic disproportion at the pelvic inlet is diagnosed when the diagonal conjugate < 11.5 cm.

Disproportion with respect to the maternal pelvis is a state where the normal proportion between the size of the fetus to the size of the pelvis is disturbed. The disparity in the relation between the head and the pelvis is called cephalopelvic disproportion.

It can either occur due to an average size baby with a small pelvis or a relatively large baby with a normal pelvis. A history of prolonged or tedious labor, followed by either spontaneous or difficult instrumental delivery is suggestive of pelvic contraction. Difficult vaginal delivery ending in a stillborn or neonatal death without any etiological factor also suggests a contracted pelvis. Past history of fracture, rickets, osteomalacia, tuberculosis of the pelvic joints or spines, and poliomyelitis is elicited.

CPD can occur at the inlet, mid pelvis, or at the pelvic outlet. It is diagnosed at these levels by the following measurements.

  • Inlet CPD
    • Anteroposterior diameter < 10 cm
    • Diagonal conjugate < 11.5 cm
    • Transverse diameter < 12 cm.
  • Midpelvis CPD
    • Sum of the interspinous and posterior sagittal diameters of the mid pelvis </= 13.5 cm
    • Interspinous diameter < 8 cm
  • Outlet CPD
    • Interischial diameter </= 8 cm.

questions.text: Regarding resuscitation and care of a neonate with suspected/symptomatic COVID-19, which of the following is true?

choices.text: All neonates should be tested at birth using serology
Indications for intubation remain unchanged in this scenario
Endotracheal administration of drugs is recommended
Breastfeeding should be avoided in the first week

questions.solution:
Guidelines for Neonatal management of a baby born to COVID19 positive mother include:

  1. Mother and child should be separated from each other.
  2. Colocation / Rooming-in should be avoided as and when possible.
  3. If the situation demands rooming-in or if the mother does not have a healthy caregiver or if she is not consenting to the separation, arrangements have to be made accordingly. A screen can be placed in between the two and a distance of 6 feet minimum can be maintained between the two. 
  4. Breastfeeding is not contraindicated in COVID19 infected mothers. 
  5. Mother can express the breastmilk using a dedicated breast pump and ask the caregiver to feed the child. If a dedicated breast pump is not available, all parts
    that come into contact with breast milk should be thoroughly washed and the entire pump should be appropriately disinfected as per the manufacturer’s instructions after each pumping session.
  6. In case the caregiver is not available, she can feed the child directly wearing a face mask and she must follow hand hygiene properly.

Guidelines regarding testing of neonates with suspected COVID-19 include:

  1. Diagnosis should be confirmed with RT-PCR and swabs can be collected from the nasopharynx, oropharynx or nasal areas. Serology testing for acute infection in neonates is not currently recommended. 
  2. All neonates born to mothers who are COVID-19 positive or who have known exposure to a person with COVID-19, regardless of whether they are symptomatic or asymptomatic, should be tested at birth or within 24 hours of age. If the initial test results are negative or unavailable, they should be tested again at 5-14 days of birth/exposure. If new symptoms develop, they should be tested immediately.
  3. At least one test should be performed prior to discharge, if discharge is anticipated prior to 48 hours. 
  4. In areas with limited testing capacity, testing should be prioritized for those neonates with signs suggestive of COVID-19 as well as those with SARS-CoV-2 exposure who require higher levels of care or who are expected to have prolonged hospitalizations depending on the mode of delivery. 

Guidelines regarding neonatal resuscitation include:

  1. Resuscitation should be done in a room earmarked for this purpose in a physically separated area. If not, at least 2m of distance should be maintained between the mother and the baby
  2. Delayed cord clamping and skin-to-skin may be practiced
  3. Mother should wear a triple layer mask and practice hand hygiene
  4. The resuscitation algorithm remains unchanged
  5. Indications for intubation are unchanged
  6. Endotracheal administration of medications should be avoided as much as possible
  7. Bathing is not recommended due to the risk of hypothermia and infections
  8. CPAP to be preferred over high flow nasal cannula and NIPPV
  9. The area providing respiratory support should be a negative-pressure area

 

 

Note:

According to CDC guidelines, if the first neonatal RT-PCR test is negative, the second test should be performed at 48 hours of age. But IAP guidelines, as mentioned above recommend doing a second test at 5-14 days.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy who is a known case of protein C deficiency presents with a painful limp on the right side. His parents give a history of limping after he comes home from playing, 1 week back. On examination,  he is afebrile. The boy whines with pain during passive movement of the hip. The range of motion is restricted in the abduction and internal rotation. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is Perthes disease.

Perthes disease, also known as Legg-Calve-Perthes disease, is the avascular necrosis of the proximal femoral epiphysis. It is most commonly seen in the age group of 4-8 years. The incidence is more in boys than girls. It is usually unilateral disease but can occur bilaterally in 10% of the cases. Risk factors include low birth weight, passive smoking, family history, low socioeconomic status, and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder. Perthes disease is associated with thrombophilia, protein C and S deficiencies.

The disease is characterized by the disruption of blood flow to the femoral head due to which the bone goes for osteonecrosis and stops growing. The lateral epiphyseal artery, a branch of the medial circumflex femoral artery is involved. Over time, healing and fibrosis occur by new blood vessels infiltrating the dead bone and removing the necrotic bone which leads to a loss of bone mass and weakening of the femoral head. 

Clinical features include pain and limping. Pain aggravates on doing any activity and relieves by rest. Physical examination reveals pain on passive movement of the hip and abduction with internal rotation movement is limited.

Xray findings depend on the stages 

  • Initial phase: Medial joint space widening and increased density in the ossific nucleus
  • Fragmentation phase: Alternating patches of sclerosis and fibrosis
  • Re-ossification phase: Complete removal of necrotic bone. Epiphyseal density is regained in this phase
  • Remodelling phase: Remodelling occurs until skeletal maturity is attained

The below radiograph shows features of bone necrosis followed by remodelling in Perthes disease.

Treatment:

Children under 6 years - symptomatic treatment including activity modification, reduction in weight-bearing, abduction bracing, bisphosphonates

Children aged 6-8 years - Operative management with proximal femoral varus osteotomy

For children aged 9 and above - operative management with pelvic osteotomy

Other options:

Option A- Developmental dysplasia of the hip is usually diagnosed in the neonatal period. The hip will be in extension and adduction with limited abduction movement. In children of walking age, a waddling or Trendelenberg gait can be seen. 

Option B- Slipped capital femoral epiphysis occurs most likely in the age group of 10-15 years with an associated endocrinal disorder.

Option D- Septic arthritis can be ruled as the boy is afebrile in the given scenario. It presents as severe tenderness and all movements are abolished due to muscle spasm.

questions.text: A 28-year-old G2P1L1, previous lower segment cesarean section, is brought to the hospital in an emergency with abdominal pain, hematuria, and vaginal bleeding. On examination, fetal bradycardia is seen and the fetal heart rate tracing is non-reassuring. The anesthetic technique of choice in this situation is____
questions.solution:
A case of previous LSCS with symptoms of abdominal pain, hematuria and signs of fetal bradycardia, and a non-reassuring fetal heart rate tracing is suggestive of uterine scar dehiscence. So, emergency cesarean section is indicated.

General anesthesia is the preferred choice considering the emergency nature of surgery and the possibility of hemodynamic instability of impending uterine rupture.

General anesthesia is preferred in certain emergency conditions such as:

  • Massive bleeding (placenta previa or accreta, abruption placentae, or uterine rupture)
  • Coagulopathy
  • Hemodynamic instabilty
  • Severe fetal distress

questions.text: A 21-year-old male patient who is an athlete presents with pruritus of the groin. Examination of the groin reveals the following findings. He is diagnosed with a fungal infection. Which of the following is the most probable causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing dry, erythematous, and a circumferential lesion in the groin is suggestive of tinea cruris. The most probable causative organism among the given options for tinea cruris is Trichophyton rubrum. 

Tinea cruris, or jock itch, refers to an infection that can involve the genital, pubic, perineal, and perianal skin. It is usually caused by dermatophytes like Trichyphyton rubrum or Epidermophyton floccosum. 

T. rubrum belongs to the dermatophyte group. Dermatophytes are classified as microsporum, trichophytoin, and epidermophyton. They are hyaline, filamentous fungi that enzymatically digest the keratin. Dermatophytes cause infection of the keratin-containing structures. These include the skin, hair, and nails. 

Infections caused by dermatophytes include the following: 

  • Tinea barbae - beard 'barber's itch' 
  • Tinea corporis - body 
  • Tinea imbricata - a type of tinea corporis that exists in the tropical climate
  • Tinea capitis - scalp 
  • Tinea cruris - groin 'jock itch'
  • Tinea pedis - foot 'athlete's foot'
  • Tinea manuum - hand
  • Tinea unguium - nails 

The examination will reveal erythematous, pruritic, circular, scaly patches.  

Diagnosis of dermatophyte infection is done with Wood's lamp which will reveal fluorescence. KOH preparation will reveal branching hyaline septate hyphae. Sabouraud dextrose agar is used to culture dermatophytes. 

Topical azoles like miconazole, clotrimazole, or terbinafine are used to treat dermatophyte infections. 

Other options: 

Option A - Exophiala weneckii causes tinea nigra, an infection of the stratum corneum in the areas of the palm leading to dark macules. 

Option C - Malassezia furfur causes pityriasis versicolor, also known as tinea versicolor. This fungus causes infection of the stratum corneum leading to discolored or depigmented macules over the thorax, abdomen, and upper limbs. 

Option D - Trichosporon beigelii causes white piedra, infection of the hair. It is characterized by firm, irregular nodules on the hair shaft.

questions.text: MRI rooms are shielded completely by a continuous sheet or wire mesh of copper to shield the imager from external electromagnetic radiation. It is called ______
questions.solution:
MRI rooms are shielded completely by a continuous sheet or wire mesh of copper called Faraday cage, which provides RF shielding.

Radiofrequency shielding in MRI is crucial to prevent both external radiofrequency pulses from interfering with the detector and the radiofrequency pulses generated by the scanner from interfering with the external environment.

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements about the deterministic effects of radiation.
  1. It is associated with damage to the DNA of cells.
  2. The severity of these effects is independent of the dose received.
  3. Examples include oligospermia, skin erythema, and epilation.
  4. Below the threshold dose, harmful effects do not occur.
  5. The fetus is more vulnerable to these effects between the 2nd to 20th week of gestation
questions.solution:
Statements 3, 4, and 5 are correct about the deterministic effects of radiation.

The harmful effects of radiation may be classified into two general categories: Stochastic effects and nonstochastic/deterministic effects.

Non-stochastic/Deterministic effects: 

These effects do not occur below a threshold dose. The severity of the effect increases as the dose increases. These effects are associated with radiation-induced killing or malfunction of cells. Skin erythema, epilation, cataracts, and transient oligospermia are a few examples of nonstochastic/deterministic effects.

The fetus is most vulnerable to deterministic effects of radiation between the 2nd and 20th week of gestation. Usually, no deterministic effects occur at a dose below 100 mGy which is the threshold for most imaging modalities.

Stochastic effects: 

Stochastic effects of ionizing radiation are chance events associated with damage to the DNA of cells. They may result in cancer or heritable effects. The incidence of these effects is directly proportionate to the dose of radiation in organs or tissues, but the severity of the effect is independent of the dose received. (All or none phenomenon)

questions.text: A 37-year-old man reports that after suffering from sudden financial loss, he developed certain symptoms 2 weeks back. He started feeling fearful that someone is about to harm him, he could not sleep or eat properly. He also began to hear voices of a female and that voice would abuse him and say that he was useless and should kill himself. His symptoms stopped after approximately one week. There was no relevant past h/o, drug abuse history, or medical history? What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A brief psychotic episode is a likely diagnosis in this scenario, as the symptoms are present for less than 30 days.

The diagnosis of brief psychotic disorder in DSM-5 is based on the presence of one or more of the following psychotic symptoms for a period of at least 1 day but less than 1 month:

1. Delusions,

2. Hallucinations,

3. Thought disorder as evidenced by disorganized speech, and

4. Disorganized or catatonic behavior.

DSM-5 specifies that one of the first three symptoms must be present for the diagnosis to be made.

Related Pearl: Psychotic disorders

Differential diagnosis of DSM-5 psychotic disorders

Psychotic disorder

 Criteria for diagnosis
Brief psychotic disorder

Sudden onset and a full return to function

Duration: > 1 day and < 1 month
Schizophreniform disorder

Same symptoms as schizophrenia and functional decline not required

Duration: > 1 month & < 6 months
Schizophrenia

Requires functional decline

At least 6 months (includes at least 1 month of active symptoms, can include prodromal and residual periods)
Schizoaffective disorder

Concurrent mood episode

Active-phase symptoms of schizophrenia with at least a 2 weeks of lifetime history of delusions or hallucinations in absence of prominent mood symptoms
Delusional disorder

One or more delusions for > 1 month

No other psychotic symptoms and normal functioning apart from the direct impact of delusions
Shared psychotic disorder (folie a deux)

Development of delusions in a person who is in a close relationship (ex: spouse, child) with someone who has a delusional disorder (the inducer)
